quizzes.question: Before HTML5, application data was stored in:
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]HTML5 Web Storage[/h1]

With HTML5 web storage, websites can store data on a user's local computer. 
Before HTML5, we had to use [b]JavaScript cookies[/b] to achieve this functionality. 

[u][b]The Advantages of Web Storage[/b][/u]
- More secure
- Faster
- Stores a larger amount of data
- Stored data is not sent with every server request
[note]Local storage is per domain. All pages from one domain can store and access the same data.[/note]

quizzes.question: What are the two types of HTML5 web storage?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Types of Web Storage Objects[/h1]

There are two types of web storage objects:
[b]- sessionStorage()[/b]
[b]- localStorage()[/b]

[u][b]Local vs. Session[/b][/u]
 - Session Storage is destroyed once the user closes the browser
 - Local Storage stores data with no expiration date
[note]You need to be familiar with basic JavaScript in order to understand and use the API.[/note]

[h1]Working with Values[/h1]

The syntax for web storage for both local and session storage is very simple and similar.
The data is stored as key/value pairs.

[b]Storing a Value:[/b] [code format="raw"]localStorage[b].setItem[/b]("key1", "value1");[/code]
[b]Getting a Value:[/b] [code format="raw"]//this will print the value
alert(localStorage.[b]getItem[/b]("key1")); [/code]
[b]Removing a Value:[/b] [code format="raw"]localStorage[b].removeItem[/b]("key1");[/code]
[b]Removing All Values:[/b] [code format="raw"]localStorage[b].clear[/b]();[/code]
[note]The same syntax applies to the session storage, with one difference: Instead of localStorage, sessionStorage is used.[/note]
